Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Detecting Glacier Calving Events from Ocean Waves and Underwater Acoustics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Predictions of future sea level rise depend on accurate estimates of the rate at which ice sheets deliver fresh water and ice to the oceans. These estimates are provided by models, which, in turn, depend on our understanding of iceberg calving, among other processes. Due to a lack of observations, our ability to project rates of iceberg calving needs improvement. This project will provide an inexpensive means of detecting and, potentially, characterizing such events.

The project will contribute to workforce development through provision of support for the training of a graduate student and a post-doctoral associate. It will enhance community resources by releasing the open source calving detection software, written in the R statistical language, on a variety of web sites.

The principal investigators of this project will develop a method for detecting and characterizing glacier calving events by measuring the surface waves generated during the process. Development of the method will make use of data already collected in Sarqardleq fjord in West Greenland. Following the project both the data and the method will be made publicly available. In addition, they will characterize the noise generated by calving events using underwater acoustic data that was collected simultaneously with the wave data. The comparison of the acoustic and surface pressure data, in conjunction with high temporal resolution time-lapse imagery, will be used to improve understanding of the details of acoustic signatures of glacier calving.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ice loss change from the Greenland Ice Sheet is due both to increased surface melt, as a result of increasing air temperatures, and glacier speed up as a result of changes at the ocean/glacier interfaces all around Greenland. The first process is reproduced relatively well in models while the second is not - thus resulting in large uncertainties in sea level rise predictions. Thus understanding how glaciers interact with the ocean and how their dynamics can change as a result of changes at the ocean end is an important part of understanding what is happening to Greenland's glaciers.

At the marine margins glaciers lose mass via two processes: submarine melting by the ocean and calving of icebergs into the ocean. Neither one of these mechanisms is well understood and models that describe both processes are largely idealized and not tested against observations. To a large extent this is due to the lack of data from the glacier marine margins. In this project we analyzed data that was collected at the edge of a marine terminating glacier in west Greenland thanks to funding from a private foundation. Specifically we used pressure sensors installed in the fjord in front of the glacier, in combination with photographs form a time-lapse camera, satellite data and other oceanographic data collected at the edge of this glacier, to reconstruct the number of calving events and their distribution along the glacier front. To do this we first had to develop a technique to extract calving information from the surface waves excited by the pieces of ice breaking from the glacier. This technique was then validated against time-lapse photographs collected during the same time period which showed calving events. The technique is described in a publication and can be utilized by other researchers to obtain calving records from different glaceirs.

Next we used remote sensing data to estimate the ice flux of this glacier and the glacier front retreat. By summing these two, we estimated what the combined submarine melting and calving have to add up to in order for this glacier to be in balance. Next we used a numerical model to estimate submarine melting and our calving record to estimate the calving flux. Our results show that the balance along a glacier front is very heterogeneous with much of the ice flux, the calving and the melting being concentrated in region where surface melt is discharged at depth. It is the first such reconstruction for a Greenland glacier and it provides a term of comparison for models attempting to reproduce glacier behavior. Our results also highlight that the estimates of melting and of the calving flux are still highly uncertain and that more, and longer-term, observations are needed to constrain these values.
